data.text: If the #COVID19 crisis prompts a radical reset of our economic and social life with policies that invest in people and reflect a shared sense of our fate as human beings, then the world will emerge resilient from this dark chapter. Read F&D magazine https://t.co/1iOfaliplV https://t.co/7lC3u6EtLm

Check out the new IMF book on how countries can end waste and improve the quality of public investment in infrastructure for a more sustainable #COVID19 recovery. https://t.co/9dCgr2gXGz https://t.co/IzMR5AutK3

Infrastructure projects like roads and bridges tend to be large, long-term, and complex—all fertile ground for #corruption & 💸💰.  Read about how countries can cut the waste https://t.co/ii8MdTINxO #IMFBlog https://t.co/uad6Tw8ulC
What is unemployment? https://t.co/91SHZ7TMzy #jobs https://t.co/JJ1kGjUdXr

The IMF Executive Board yesterday approved the disbursement of US$52 million to #Mauritania under the current ECF arrangement. This includes an additional US$29 million to help address financing needs from the #COVID19 pandemic. https://t.co/O5HPZ1x6q8 https://t.co/OGgHoSzv94

The pandemic is straining economic and social fault lines: the only remedy is international cooperation, argues @ian_goldin in our new issue of F&D. Read his article “Rethinking Global Resilience” here: https://t.co/TnqDCaHVnl https://t.co/bKbEFLEpag
How strong infrastructure governance can end waste in #publicinvestment: read the new #IMFBlog https://t.co/ii8MdTINxO https://t.co/1D7HnRUFym

#COVID19 has painfully exposed and widened existing economic and social divisions and created new ones. How can we have a future that heals these fractures and is more resilient? #IMFBlog https://t.co/U0uNNi0IjS https://t.co/1f1L0bpU0I

A drop in tourism due to #COVID19 could have an outsized impact on the current account balances of economies that rely on foreign travelers. Find out more in the #ChartOfTheWeek on #IMFblog. https://t.co/SfF3NljQHf

The #COVID19 crisis and the fault lines it is exposing are inspiring calls to rethink priorities and reconsider the very structure of the world economy, toward a future that is more equitable, adaptable, and sustainable—more resilient. Learn more in the new Sept issue of F&D ⬇️

The permanent loss of productive capacity as a result of the #COVID19 pandemic would trigger severe setbacks to development efforts in low-income developing countries, including undoing the gains in poverty reduction of the last 7 to 10 years. https://t.co/uXu0IErBdu #IMFBlog https://t.co/24pUk20jF1

We’ve just launched our September 2020 issue of Finance & Development (F&D) magazine, which focuses on resilience in this age of countless challenges and unknowns. Find our new issue here: https://t.co/TQ5y10AOdb https://t.co/EkZmUaE3r9

Despite the best efforts of governments in low-income developing countries to address the impact of #COVID19, lasting damage seems unavoidable in the absence of more international support. More on #IMFBlog: https://t.co/uXu0IErBdu
